On 19/12/2007, tansey@... <tansey@...> wrote:
>
> Quoting Colin Green <locster01@...>:
> > I was wondering what current users (user?) of SharpNeat would think
> > about switching to a Java code base
>
> On one hand, I'd have to rewrite distributed SharpNeat over again. This wouldn't
> necessarily be a big deal, but in general .NET Remoting is much better than Java
> RMI from a design level. Also, GUI development in Java is a horrendous ordeal
> compared to VS and the resulting front end has a tendency to look like an OS/2
> program.

Yes the GUI side of things concerns me, and I think some of the GUI
stuff is important - it's not just the core NEAT code I'm thinking of
here - visualisation matters.

I hadn't considered remoting API's, but that's another good point.



> On the other hand, I agree that Java is the preferred language for most research
> nowadays, and the cross platform compatibility is a big plus.

With regards to cross platform support there is Mono and dotGNU, and
then on the IDE front you have MonoDevelop and SharpDevelop, so it's
not a complete dead-end, but regardless of these acceptance of .Net/C#
in academia is an important aspect to consider.



> Personally, I'd say if you can do it without requiring too many changes to the
> API, go for it. At the end of the day, SharpNeat is a means to an end for most
> people, not the end itself. Whether it's C# or Java, I think what most people
> are interested in is really just the XML ANN that it produces.


Yes and no. In my experience it takes a lot of tweaking and rethinking
of fitness functions before you get to a useable ANN. Being able to
visualise the speciation, networks, progress graphs is really useful
in tracking what is going on, what is going wrong, etc. It's an
iterative process that leads you to a good fitness function and the
right NEAT parameters.


>
> > Oh and the other issue is that of support for generics/templates. Both
> > Java and .Net have this now but in the Java world generics are still
> > just language level constructs -
>
> I wouldn't hold my breath on that happening.


From a quick google it seems that it is being discussed for Java 7,
but yeh, I won't hold my breath there. see
http://tech.puredanger.com/java7#reified



> Nevertheless, all that you're going to lose from
> an efficiency standpoint is having to call CHECKCAST in the bytecode a few
> times. That's not a big deal.


Well, potentially a few million CHECKCAST's per second :) But no it's
not a *big* deal.


Thanks for the feedback, I'm going to have a look at VS 2008 as you
can d/load 90-day trial versons for free right now. Also I'll have a
look at using a standalone SVN/CVS tool such as TortoiseSVN (or indeed
Eclipse).

Colin.
